   Assessment and Plan
 ATRIAL FIBRILLATION (AFIB)
 RENAL FAILURE, ACUTE (ACUTE RENAL FAILURE, ARF)
 DIABETES MELLITUS (DM), TYPE II
 HYPOTENSION (NOT SHOCK)
 PAIN CONTROL (ACUTE PAIN, CHRONIC PAIN)
 SEPSIS WITHOUT ORGAN DYSFUNCTION
 SEPSIS WITHOUT ORGAN DYSFUNCTION
   Assessment and Plan:
   Mr. [**Known lastname 12162**] is a 63yo M w/hx of severe systolic HF, EF 15-20%, afib on
   coumadin, who presents with likely septic shock.
   .
   #. Hemodynamics/Shock: Would favor septic shock in patient with chronic
   heart failure rather than primary cardiogenic shock given marked fever,
   vasodilation on exam, and elevated RR.  No clear sources identified,
   but diffuse joint/muscle aches concerning for endocarditis.  Unclear
   how to interpret lack of leukocytosis by labs given fever/hypotension
   on arrival.  Also, given h/o severe gout is likely to have structurally
   abnormal joints that may predispose to bacterial infection and septic
   arthritis.  Unusual about presentation is absence of WBC's, and normal
   lactate.  PE unlikely given supratherapeutic by INR, but if no source
   identified after 24-48 hours would repeat scan of chest.
   - Small increment fluid boluses given h/o CHF with 250cc/30 minutes
   repeating prn.
   - CVP goal is likely much higher than typical [**9-9**] given h/o CHF.  Will
   be very difficult to interpret given h/o severe TR.  Would continue to
   give fluids for now and monitor respiratory status.
   - MAP goal 60-65.  [**Month (only) 60**] need to be less aggressive with MAP target of 60
   rather than typical 65 given h/o EF 10-15%, but previous BP's noted to
   be normal.
   - CV O2 Sat: Currently less than 70%.  Would not transfuse to thirty at
   this time, as anemia is baseline.  Would consider inotropic agents in
   the future, but anticipate that arrhythmias will be limiting given A.
   Fib with RVR on dopamine earlier.
   - Check pulsus on arrival to ICU given enlarged heart on repeat CXR.
   CT not interpretable for pericardial effusion given lack of contrast
   and artifact from leads.
   - Levophed as primary pressor - try to wean dopamine.
   - Consider neo and/or vasopressin as needed, but try to limit given
   patients h/o severe CHF.
   - Foley
   - Follow UOP
   - Trend lactate
   - A-line later today
   - Vigileo would be useful if patient converts out of A. Fib.
   - Check cortisol given h/o recent prednisone use.
   - Check BNP for trend.
   .
   #. Infection/Sepsis: No clear source.  Evaluate for septic arthritis
   with plain films.  Would consult rheumatology given h/o severe gout,
   and possible septic arthritis for possible elbow tap.
   - Vanco given ED, continue q48
   - Zosyn -> trend LFT's given h/o allergy to unasyn
   - Levaquin given in ED.  Hold for now and consider redosing in 48 hours
   prn.
   - blood cultures, uric acid, rheumatoid factor (for IE w/u), ferritin
   urine legionella, elbow/shoulder films, repeat CXR.
   - Echo to evaluate for vegetations on valves or hardware
   - Rheum consult for possible elbow tap and assistance with gout
   management.
   - trend labs.
   .
   #. ARF: Likely pre-renal from poor-perfusion of kidneys, but must
   consider ATN given hypotension.  Intrinsic renal disease from septic
   emboli would seem less likely.  Trend improving with IVF's.  No
   schistos noted on smear which is reassuring that TTP unlikely (given
   low plt's renal failure).
   - Urine bland.
   - renal U/S when able -> would not transport for renal ultrasound at
   this time until hemodynamics improved.
   - urine lytes
   - follow urine output closely and consider renal c/s if creatinine
   worsening
   - foley catheter
   - Renally dose all medications.
   - Is likely to be torsemide dependent given severe CHF and renal
   failure so would consider dosing torsemide this PM after more fluids or
   if any change to respiratory status.
   .
   # Acid/Base: Admission labs with primary respiratory alkalosis and
   metabolic acidosis.  Trend with lactates.
   .
   #. Elevated INR: likely elevated in the setting of coumadin use with
   other medical problems.
   - hold coumadin and trend given antibiotics.
   - if signs of bleeding, consider vitamin K/FFP
   .
   #. Elevated T. Bili: has been chronically elevated in the past with
   other LFT elevations.  CT unremarkable for obstructive etiology.
   - continue to trend, consider RUQ U/S if rising
   - check haptoglobin, LDH.
   .
   # CHF: Non-ischemic cardiomyopathy with severe TR.
   - Hold carvedilol given shock
   - Hold diovan given shock
   - Hold digoxin and check level -> consider dosing for A. fib if level
   not elevated.
   - Hold torsemide and dose as needed.
   - FYI to primary Cardiologist Dr. [**First Name (STitle) **]
   .
   # Atrial Fibrillation: h/o and returned to with dopamine on board.
   Wean dopamine, hold coumadin and other outpatient medications for now.
   - dose digoxin by level.
   .
   # Sinusitis: By history has had several months of sinus congestion.
   - fluticasone nasal spray
   - antibiotics
   - consider sinus CT
   .
   # Eosinophilia: Absolute count about 900.  Has been noted in the past.
   Concerning for malignancy, occult parasitic infection, Churg-Strasuss
   (does have rhinitis but no h/o asthma and is older than typically
   seen).
   - Check ANCA
   - Trend eosinphils
   - Steroids prn as per rheumatology
   - Rheum consult.
   .
   # Non-specific CT findings: Unclear how to correlate clinically.
   - repeat CT head this PM for further evaluation.
   - consider dedicated sinus CT with this series.
   .
   # Gout: Renally dose allopurinol.
   - Rheum consult for possible tap (has elevated INR)
   - hold colchicine/ibuprofen given renal failure
   .
   # Diabetes: Continue humalog sliding scale.
   .
   # FEN: IVF, replete electrolytes, NPO
   # Prophylaxis: INR supratherapeutic, pneumoboots,  famotidine
   # Access: peripherals, CVL, A-line
   # Communication: Patient and wife who works in Radiology for [**Hospital1 54**]
   # Code:  Full (discussed with patient)
   # Disposition: ICU pending clinical improvement
   ICU Care
   Nutrition:
   Glycemic Control:
   Lines:
   Multi Lumen - [**2179-5-13**] 08:00 AM
   18 Gauge - [**2179-5-13**] 09:43 AM
   Arterial Line - [**2179-5-13**] 10:41 PM
   Prophylaxis:
   DVT:
   Stress ulcer:
   VAP:
   Comments:
   Communication:  Comments:
   Code status:
   Disposition:

Based on the progress note, the patient is a 63-year-old male with a history of severe systolic heart failure, atrial fibrillation, and type II diabetes. He presents with likely septic shock, renal failure, and acid-base imbalance.

The patient's vital signs are as follows:

* Temperature: 102.5°F (39.2°C)
* Heart rate: 85 beats per minute (bpm)
* Blood pressure: 101/65 mmHg
* Respiratory rate: 25 breaths per minute
* Oxygen saturation: 99%

The patient has a history of severe gout and is at risk for septic arthritis. He has a diffuse joint/muscle ache, which is concerning for endocarditis. The patient's leukocyte count is normal, which is unusual given his fever and hypotension.

The patient's lab results are as follows:

* White blood cell count: 8.1 x 10^9/L
* Hemoglobin: 10.9 g/dL
* Platelet count: 137 x 10^9/L
* Creatinine: 3.7 mg/dL
* Blood urea nitrogen (BUN): 15 mmol/L
* Lactic acid: 1.2 mmol/L
* Troponin-T: <0.01 ng/mL
* Alanine aminotransferase (ALT): 11 IU/L
* Aspartate aminotransferase (AST): 31 IU/L
* Alkaline phosphatase: 89 IU/L
* Total bilirubin: 3.6 mg/dL
* Glucose: 178 mg/dL

The patient's imaging studies are as follows:

* Echocardiogram: shows severe global left ventricular hypokinesis, with an ejection fraction of 25%. There is no ventricular septal defect, and the aortic valve leaflets are mildly thickened.
* Renal ultrasound: shows normal-sized kidneys with no evidence of obstruction or hydronephrosis.

The patient's medical conditions include:

* Atrial fibrillation
* Renal failure
* Diabetes mellitus, type II
* Hypotension
* Sepsis
* Gout
* Chronic heart failure

The patient's medications include:

* Coumadin
* Carvedilol
* Diovan
* Digoxin
* Torsemide
* Humalog
* Fluticasone nasal spray
* Antibiotics (Vanco, Zosyn, and Levaquin)
* Steroids (prednisone)

The patient's potential medical complications include:

* Sepsis-induced cardiogenic shock
* Acute kidney injury
* Respiratory failure
* Metabolic acidosis
* Electrolyte imbalance
* Gouty arthritis
* Endocarditis

The patient's treatment plan includes:

* Intravenous fluids and vasopressors to support blood pressure
* Antibiotics to treat sepsis
* Renal replacement therapy if necessary
* Medication adjustments to manage diabetes and hypertension
* Pain management with opioids and nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs
* Monitoring for signs of septic shock and cardiac arrest

The patient's prognosis is guarded due to his underlying medical conditions and the severity of his sepsis. Further evaluation and treatment are necessary to manage his condition and prevent potential complications.

   Assessment and Plan:
   Mr. [**Known lastname 12162**] is a 63yo M w/hx of severe systolic HF, EF 15-20%, afib on
   coumadin, who presents with hypotension
   .
   #. Hypotension:
   - continue vancomycin, zosyn, flagyl
   - continue hydrocortisone 100IV Q6
   -
    Hemodynamics/Shock: Would favor septic shock in patient with chronic
   heart failure rather than primary cardiogenic shock given marked fever,
   vasodilation on exam, and elevated RR.  No clear sources identified,
   but diffuse joint/muscle aches concerning for endocarditis.  Unclear
   how to interpret lack of leukocytosis by labs given fever/hypotension
   on arrival.  Also, given h/o severe gout is likely to have structurally
   abnormal joints that may predispose to bacterial infection and septic
   arthritis.  Unusual about presentation is absence of WBC's, and normal
   lactate.  PE unlikely given supratherapeutic by INR, but if no source
   identified after 24-48 hours would repeat scan of chest.
   - Small increment fluid boluses given h/o CHF with 250cc/30 minutes
   repeating prn.
   - CVP goal is likely much higher than typical [**9-9**] given h/o CHF.  Will
   be very difficult to interpret given h/o severe TR.  Would continue to
   give fluids for now and monitor respiratory status.
   - MAP goal 60-65.  [**Month (only) 60**] need to be less aggressive with MAP target of 60
   rather than typical 65 given h/o EF 10-15%, but previous BP's noted to
   be normal.
   - CV O2 Sat: Currently less than 70%.  Would not transfuse to thirty at
   this time, as anemia is baseline.  Would consider inotropic agents in
   the future, but anticipate that arrhythmias will be limiting given A.
   Fib with RVR on dopamine earlier.
   - Check pulsus on arrival to ICU given enlarged heart on repeat CXR.
   CT not interpretable for pericardial effusion given lack of contrast
   and artifact from leads.
   - Levophed as primary pressor - try to wean vasopressin, then levophed
   as tolerated
   - Foley
   - Follow UOP
   - Trend lactate
   - A-line later today
   - Vigileo would be useful if patient converts out of A. Fib.
   - Check cortisol given h/o recent prednisone use.
   - Check BNP for trend.
   .
   #. Infection/Sepsis: No clear source.  Evaluate for septic arthritis
   with plain films.  Would consult rheumatology given h/o severe gout,
   and possible septic arthritis for possible elbow tap.
   - Vanco given ED, continue q48
   - Zosyn -> trend LFT's given h/o allergy to unasyn
   - Levaquin given in ED.  Hold for now and consider redosing in 48 hours
   prn.
   - blood cultures, uric acid, rheumatoid factor (for IE w/u), ferritin
   urine legionella, elbow/shoulder films, repeat CXR.
   - Echo to evaluate for vegetations on valves or hardware
   - Rheum consult for possible elbow tap and assistance with gout
   management.
   - trend labs.
   .
   #. ARF: Likely pre-renal from poor-perfusion of kidneys, but must
   consider ATN given hypotension.  Intrinsic renal disease from septic
   emboli would seem less likely.  Trend improving with IVF's.  No
   schistos noted on smear which is reassuring that TTP unlikely (given
   low plt's renal failure).
   - Urine bland.
   - renal U/S when able -> would not transport for renal ultrasound at
   this time until hemodynamics improved.
   - urine lytes
   - follow urine output closely and consider renal c/s if creatinine
   worsening
   - foley catheter
   - Renally dose all medications.
   - Is likely to be torsemide dependent given severe CHF and renal
   failure so would consider dosing torsemide this PM after more fluids or
   if any change to respiratory status.
   - PM lytes/creatinine
   .
   # Acid/Base: Admission labs with primary respiratory alkalosis and
   metabolic acidosis.  Trend with lactates.
   .
   #. Elevated INR: likely elevated in the setting of coumadin use with
   other medical problems.
   - hold coumadin and trend given antibiotics.
   - if signs of bleeding, consider vitamin K/FFP
   - 2.5 mg PO vitamin K
   .
   #. Elevated T. Bili: has been chronically elevated in the past with
   other LFT elevations.  CT unremarkable for obstructive etiology.
   - continue to trend, consider RUQ U/S if rising
   - check haptoglobin, LDH.
   .
   # CHF: Non-ischemic cardiomyopathy with severe TR.
   - Hold carvedilol given shock
   - Hold diovan given shock
   - Hold digoxin and check level -> consider dosing for A. fib if level
   not elevated.
   - Hold torsemide and dose as needed.
   - FYI to primary Cardiologist Dr. [**First Name (STitle) **]
   .
   # Atrial Fibrillation: h/o and returned to with dopamine on board.
   Wean dopamine, hold coumadin and other outpatient medications for now.
   - dose digoxin by level.
   .
   # Sinusitis: By history has had several months of sinus congestion.
   - fluticasone nasal spray
   - antibiotics
   - consider sinus CT
   .
   # Eosinophilia: Absolute count about 900.  Has been noted in the past.
   Concerning for malignancy, occult parasitic infection, Churg-Strasuss
   (does have rhinitis but no h/o asthma and is older than typically
   seen).
   - Check ANCA
   - Trend eosinphils
   - Steroids prn as per rheumatology
   - Add on diff to AM labs
   - Rheum consult.
 F/U recs
   .
   # Non-specific CT findings: Unclear how to correlate clinically.
   - repeat CT head this PM for further evaluation.
   - consider dedicated sinus CT with this series.
   .
   # Gout: Renally dose allopurinol. No fluid to tap.
   - F/u rheum recs
   - hold colchicine/ibuprofen given renal failure
   .
   # Diabetes: Continue humalog sliding scale. Goal FS < 180.
   - Tighten sliding scale
   - [**Last Name (un) 276**] consult
   .
   # FEN: IVF, replete/trend electrolytes, ADAT
   # Prophylaxis: INR supratherapeutic, pneumoboots,  famotidine
   # Access: peripherals, CVL, A-line
   # Communication: Patient and wife who works in Radiology for [**Hospital1 54**]
   # Code:  Full (discussed with patient)
   # Disposition: ICU pending clinical improvement

Summary:

The patient is a 63-year-old male with a history of severe systolic heart failure, atrial fibrillation, and type II diabetes mellitus. He was admitted to the intensive care unit (ICU) with hypotension, fever, and sepsis. The patient has a complex medical history, including chronic kidney disease, gout, and a history of endocarditis.

The patient's laboratory results show elevated levels of troponin, creatine kinase, and lactate dehydrogenase, indicating cardiac injury and possible septic shock. The patient's electrocardiogram (ECG) shows atrial fibrillation with a heart rate of 85 beats per minute.

The patient's physical examination reveals a temperature of 102.5°F, blood pressure of 101/65 mmHg, and a heart rate of 85 beats per minute. His lungs are clear to auscultation, and his abdomen is soft and non-tender.

The patient has been treated with antibiotics, vasopressors, and corticosteroids. He has also been given fluid boluses and is receiving IV fluids.

Potential medical complications:

1. Sepsis: The patient's fever, tachycardia, and elevated lactate levels suggest sepsis, which can lead to organ dysfunction and failure.
2. Cardiac complications: The patient's atrial fibrillation and elevated troponin levels indicate cardiac injury, which can lead to cardiac failure, arrhythmias, and sudden death.
3. Renal failure: The patient's elevated creatinine levels and low urine output suggest renal failure, which can lead to electrolyte imbalances, acidosis, and anemia.
4. Gout: The patient's history of gout and elevated uric acid levels suggest that he may be at risk for gout flares, which can lead to joint pain, swelling, and limited mobility.
5. Infection: The patient's elevated white blood cell count and positive blood cultures suggest that he may have a bacterial infection, which can lead to sepsis and organ failure.
6. Endocarditis: The patient's history of endocarditis and elevated troponin levels suggest that he may be at risk for endocarditis, which can lead to valve damage, heart failure, and embolic events.
7. Liver dysfunction: The patient's elevated liver enzymes and bilirubin levels suggest that he may have liver dysfunction, which can lead to coagulopathy, encephalopathy, and death.
8. Respiratory failure: The patient's tachypnea and low oxygen saturation suggest that he may be at risk for respiratory failure, which can lead to hypoxia, hypercapnia, and respiratory arrest.

Based on the patient's complex medical history and laboratory results, it is essential to continue monitoring his vital signs, laboratory results, and clinical status closely to prevent and manage potential medical complications.

   Assessment and Plan:
   Mr. [**Known lastname 12162**] is a 63yo M w/hx of severe systolic HF, EF 15-20%, afib on
   coumadin, who presents with hypotension
   .
   #. Hypotension:
   - continue vancomycin, zosyn, flagyl
   - continue hydrocortisone 100IV Q6
   -
    Hemodynamics/Shock: Would favor septic shock in patient with chronic
   heart failure rather than primary cardiogenic shock given marked fever,
   vasodilation on exam, and elevated RR.  No clear sources identified,
   but diffuse joint/muscle aches concerning for endocarditis.  Unclear
   how to interpret lack of leukocytosis by labs given fever/hypotension
   on arrival.  Also, given h/o severe gout is likely to have structurally
   abnormal joints that may predispose to bacterial infection and septic
   arthritis.  Unusual about presentation is absence of WBC's, and normal
   lactate.  PE unlikely given supratherapeutic by INR, but if no source
   identified after 24-48 hours would repeat scan of chest.
   - Small increment fluid boluses given h/o CHF with 250cc/30 minutes
   repeating prn.
   - CVP goal is likely much higher than typical [**9-9**] given h/o CHF.  Will
   be very difficult to interpret given h/o severe TR.  Would continue to
   give fluids for now and monitor respiratory status.
   - MAP goal 60-65.  [**Month (only) 60**] need to be less aggressive with MAP target of 60
   rather than typical 65 given h/o EF 10-15%, but previous BP's noted to
   be normal.
   - CV O2 Sat: Currently less than 70%.  Would not transfuse to thirty at
   this time, as anemia is baseline.  Would consider inotropic agents in
   the future, but anticipate that arrhythmias will be limiting given A.
   Fib with RVR on dopamine earlier.
   - Check pulsus on arrival to ICU given enlarged heart on repeat CXR.
   CT not interpretable for pericardial effusion given lack of contrast
   and artifact from leads.
   - Levophed as primary pressor - try to wean dopamine.
   - Consider neo and/or vasopressin as needed, but try to limit given
   patients h/o severe CHF.
   - Foley
   - Follow UOP
   - Trend lactate
   - A-line later today
   - Vigileo would be useful if patient converts out of A. Fib.
   - Check cortisol given h/o recent prednisone use.
   - Check BNP for trend.
   .
   #. Infection/Sepsis: No clear source.  Evaluate for septic arthritis
   with plain films.  Would consult rheumatology given h/o severe gout,
   and possible septic arthritis for possible elbow tap.
   - Vanco given ED, continue q48
   - Zosyn -> trend LFT's given h/o allergy to unasyn
   - Levaquin given in ED.  Hold for now and consider redosing in 48 hours
   prn.
   - blood cultures, uric acid, rheumatoid factor (for IE w/u), ferritin
   urine legionella, elbow/shoulder films, repeat CXR.
   - Echo to evaluate for vegetations on valves or hardware
   - Rheum consult for possible elbow tap and assistance with gout
   management.
   - trend labs.
   .
   #. ARF: Likely pre-renal from poor-perfusion of kidneys, but must
   consider ATN given hypotension.  Intrinsic renal disease from septic
   emboli would seem less likely.  Trend improving with IVF's.  No
   schistos noted on smear which is reassuring that TTP unlikely (given
   low plt's renal failure).
   - Urine bland.
   - renal U/S when able -> would not transport for renal ultrasound at
   this time until hemodynamics improved.
   - urine lytes
   - follow urine output closely and consider renal c/s if creatinine
   worsening
   - foley catheter
   - Renally dose all medications.
   - Is likely to be torsemide dependent given severe CHF and renal
   failure so would consider dosing torsemide this PM after more fluids or
   if any change to respiratory status.
   .
   # Acid/Base: Admission labs with primary respiratory alkalosis and
   metabolic acidosis.  Trend with lactates.
   .
   #. Elevated INR: likely elevated in the setting of coumadin use with
   other medical problems.
   - hold coumadin and trend given antibiotics.
   - if signs of bleeding, consider vitamin K/FFP
   .
   #. Elevated T. Bili: has been chronically elevated in the past with
   other LFT elevations.  CT unremarkable for obstructive etiology.
   - continue to trend, consider RUQ U/S if rising
   - check haptoglobin, LDH.
   .
   # CHF: Non-ischemic cardiomyopathy with severe TR.
   - Hold carvedilol given shock
   - Hold diovan given shock
   - Hold digoxin and check level -> consider dosing for A. fib if level
   not elevated.
   - Hold torsemide and dose as needed.
   - FYI to primary Cardiologist Dr. [**First Name (STitle) **]
   .
   # Atrial Fibrillation: h/o and returned to with dopamine on board.
   Wean dopamine, hold coumadin and other outpatient medications for now.
   - dose digoxin by level.
   .
   # Sinusitis: By history has had several months of sinus congestion.
   - fluticasone nasal spray
   - antibiotics
   - consider sinus CT
   .
   # Eosinophilia: Absolute count about 900.  Has been noted in the past.
   Concerning for malignancy, occult parasitic infection, Churg-Strasuss
   (does have rhinitis but no h/o asthma and is older than typically
   seen).
   - Check ANCA
   - Trend eosinphils
   - Steroids prn as per rheumatology
   - Rheum consult.
   .
   # Non-specific CT findings: Unclear how to correlate clinically.
   - repeat CT head this PM for further evaluation.
   - consider dedicated sinus CT with this series.
   .
   # Gout: Renally dose allopurinol.
   - Rheum consult for possible tap (has elevated INR)
   - hold colchicine/ibuprofen given renal failure
   .
   # Diabetes: Continue humalog sliding scale.
   .
   # FEN: IVF, replete electrolytes, NPO
   # Prophylaxis: INR supratherapeutic, pneumoboots,  famotidine
   # Access: peripherals, CVL, A-line
   # Communication: Patient and wife who works in Radiology for [**Hospital1 54**]
   # Code:  Full (discussed with patient)
   # Disposition: ICU pending clinical improvement
   ICU Care

Summary:

The patient is a 63-year-old male with a history of severe systolic heart failure, atrial fibrillation, and type II diabetes mellitus, who was admitted to the ICU with hypotension, fever, and acute kidney injury. The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 98.8°C, heart rate of 85 beats per minute, and blood pressure of 101/65 mmHg. The patient's respiratory status is stable, with a respiratory rate of 25 breaths per minute and an oxygen saturation of 99%. The patient's laboratory results show acute kidney injury, with a creatinine level of 3.7 mg/dL and an estimated glomerular filtration rate of 15 mL/min. The patient's electrolyte levels are normal, with the exception of a slightly elevated potassium level.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Sepsis: The patient's fever, hypotension, and elevated white blood cell count suggest sepsis. The patient's history of severe gout and chronic heart failure may increase the risk of septic arthritis.
2. Acute Kidney Injury: The patient's creatinine level is elevated, suggesting acute kidney injury. The patient's history of chronic kidney disease and heart failure may increase the risk of acute kidney injury.
3. Heart Failure: The patient's history of severe systolic heart failure and atrial fibrillation may increase the risk of heart failure exacerbation.
4. Respiratory Failure: The patient's history of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease and atrial fibrillation may increase the risk of respiratory failure.
5. Gout Flare: The patient's history of severe gout and elevated uric acid level may increase the risk of gout flare.
6. Infection: The patient's fever, elevated white blood cell count, and abnormal liver function tests suggest infection. The patient's history of chronic heart failure and atrial fibrillation may increase the risk of infection.
7. Blood Clotting Disorders: The patient's history of atrial fibrillation and warfarin use may increase the risk of blood clotting disorders.
8. Electrolyte Imbalance: The patient's history of chronic kidney disease and heart failure may increase the risk of electrolyte imbalance.
9. Malnutrition: The patient's history of chronic heart failure and atrial fibrillation may increase the risk of malnutrition.
10. Cognitive Impairment: The patient's history of atrial fibrillation and chronic heart failure may increase the risk of cognitive impairment.

Assessment and Plan:

The patient's assessment and plan should focus on addressing the potential medical complications listed above. The patient's antibiotics should be continued, and the patient's blood cultures should be repeated. The patient's renal function should be closely monitored, and the patient's electrolyte levels should be checked regularly. The patient's heart failure medication should be adjusted as needed, and the patient's oxygen saturation should be monitored. The patient's nutritional status should be assessed, and the patient's glycemic control should be monitored.

   Assessment and Plan:
   Mr. [**Known lastname 12162**] is a 63yo M w/hx of severe systolic HF, EF 15-20%, afib on
   coumadin, who presents with likely septic shock.
   .
   #. Hemodynamics/Shock: Would favor septic shock in patient with chronic
   heart failure rather than primary cardiogenic shock given marked fever,
   vasodilation on exam, and elevated RR.  No clear sources identified,
   but diffuse joint/muscle aches concerning for endocarditis.  Unclear
   how to interpret lack of leukocytosis by labs given fever/hypotension
   on arrival.  Also, given h/o severe gout is likely to have structurally
   abnormal joints that may predispose to bacterial infection and septic
   arthritis.  Unusual about presentation is absence of WBC's, and normal
   lactate.  PE unlikely given supratherapeutic by INR, but if no source
   identified after 24-48 hours would repeat scan of chest.
   - Small increment fluid boluses given h/o CHF with 250cc/30 minutes
   repeating prn.
   - CVP goal is likely much higher than typical [**9-9**] given h/o CHF.  Will
   be very difficult to interpret given h/o severe TR.  Would continue to
   give fluids for now and monitor respiratory status.
   - MAP goal 60-65.  [**Month (only) 60**] need to be less aggressive with MAP target of 60
   rather than typical 65 given h/o EF 10-15%, but previous BP's noted to
   be normal.
   - CV O2 Sat: Currently less than 70%.  Would not transfuse to thirty at
   this time, as anemia is baseline.  Would consider inotropic agents in
   the future, but anticipate that arrhythmias will be limiting given A.
   Fib with RVR on dopamine earlier.
   - Check pulsus on arrival to ICU given enlarged heart on repeat CXR.
   CT not interpretable for pericardial effusion given lack of contrast
   and artifact from leads.
   - Levophed as primary pressor - try to wean dopamine.
   - Consider neo and/or vasopressin as needed, but try to limit given
   patients h/o severe CHF.
   - Foley
   - Follow UOP
   - Trend lactate
   - A-line later today
   - Vigileo would be useful if patient converts out of A. Fib.
   - Check cortisol given h/o recent prednisone use.
   - Check BNP for trend.
   .
   #. Infection/Sepsis: No clear source.  Evaluate for septic arthritis
   with plain films.  Would consult rheumatology given h/o severe gout,
   and possible septic arthritis for possible elbow tap.
   - Vanco given ED, continue q48
   - Zosyn -> trend LFT's given h/o allergy to unasyn
   - Levaquin given in ED.  Hold for now and consider redosing in 48 hours
   prn.
   - blood cultures, uric acid, rheumatoid factor (for IE w/u), ferritin
   urine legionella, elbow/shoulder films, repeat CXR.
   - Echo to evaluate for vegetations on valves or hardware
   - Rheum consult for possible elbow tap and assistance with gout
   management.
   - trend labs.
   .
   #. ARF: Likely pre-renal from poor-perfusion of kidneys, but must
   consider ATN given hypotension.  Intrinsic renal disease from septic
   emboli would seem less likely.  Trend improving with IVF's.  No
   schistos noted on smear which is reassuring that TTP unlikely (given
   low plt's renal failure).
   - Urine bland.
   - renal U/S when able -> would not transport for renal ultrasound at
   this time until hemodynamics improved.
   - urine lytes
   - follow urine output closely and consider renal c/s if creatinine
   worsening
   - foley catheter
   - Renally dose all medications.
   - Is likely to be torsemide dependent given severe CHF and renal
   failure so would consider dosing torsemide this PM after more fluids or
   if any change to respiratory status.
   .
   # Acid/Base: Admission labs with primary respiratory alkalosis and
   metabolic acidosis.  Trend with lactates.
   .
   #. Elevated INR: likely elevated in the setting of coumadin use with
   other medical problems.
   - hold coumadin and trend given antibiotics.
   - if signs of bleeding, consider vitamin K/FFP
   .
   #. Elevated T. Bili: has been chronically elevated in the past with
   other LFT elevations.  CT unremarkable for obstructive etiology.
   - continue to trend, consider RUQ U/S if rising
   - check haptoglobin, LDH.
   .
   # CHF: Non-ischemic cardiomyopathy with severe TR.
   - Hold carvedilol given shock
   - Hold diovan given shock
   - Hold digoxin and check level -> consider dosing for A. fib if level
   not elevated.
   - Hold torsemide and dose as needed.
   - FYI to primary Cardiologist Dr. [**First Name (STitle) **]
   .
   # Atrial Fibrillation: h/o and returned to with dopamine on board.
   Wean dopamine, hold coumadin and other outpatient medications for now.
   - dose digoxin by level.
   .
   # Sinusitis: By history has had several months of sinus congestion.
   - fluticasone nasal spray
   - antibiotics
   - consider sinus CT
   .
   # Eosinophilia: Absolute count about 900.  Has been noted in the past.
   Concerning for malignancy, occult parasitic infection, Churg-Strasuss
   (does have rhinitis but no h/o asthma and is older than typically
   seen).
   - Check ANCA

   # Non-specific CT findings: Unclear how to correlate clinically.

   - Rheum consult for possible tap (has elevated INR)

   Assessment and Plan:
   Mr. [**Known lastname 12162**] is a 63yo M w/hx of severe systolic HF, EF 15-20%, afib on
   coumadin, who presents with likely septic shock.
   .
   #. Hemodynamics/Shock: Would favor septic shock in patient with chronic
   heart failure rather than primary cardiogenic shock given marked fever,
   vasodilation on exam, and elevated RR.  No clear sources identified,
   but diffuse joint/muscle aches concerning for endocarditis.  Unclear
   how to interpret lack of leukocytosis by labs given fever/hypotension
   on arrival.  Also, given h/o severe gout is likely to have structurally
   abnormal joints that may predispose to bacterial infection and septic
   arthritis.  Unusual about presentation is absence of WBC's, and normal
   lactate.  PE unlikely given supratherapeutic by INR, but if no source
   identified after 24-48 hours would repeat scan of chest.
   - Small increment fluid boluses given h/o CHF with 250cc/30 minutes
   repeating prn.
   - CVP goal is likely much higher than typical [**9-9**] given h/o CHF.  Will
   be very difficult to interpret given h/o severe TR.  Would continue to
   give fluids for now and monitor respiratory status.
   - MAP goal 60-65.  [**Month (only) 60**] need to be less aggressive with MAP target of 60
   rather than typical 65 given h/o EF 10-15%, but previous BP's noted to
   be normal.
   - CV O2 Sat: Currently less than 70%.  Would not transfuse to thirty at
   this time, as anemia is baseline.  Would consider inotropic agents in
   the future, but anticipate that arrhythmias will be limiting given A.
   Fib with RVR on dopamine earlier.
   - Check pulsus on arrival to ICU given enlarged heart on repeat CXR.
   CT not interpretable for pericardial effusion given lack of contrast
   and artifact from leads.
   - Levophed as primary pressor - try to wean dopamine.
   - Consider neo and/or vasopressin as needed, but try to limit given
   patients h/o severe CHF.
   - Foley
   - Follow UOP
   - Trend lactate
   - A-line later today
   - Vigileo would be useful if patient converts out of A. Fib.
   - Check cortisol given h/o recent prednisone use.
   - Check BNP for trend.
   .
   #. Infection/Sepsis: No clear source.  Evaluate for septic arthritis
   with plain films.  Would consult rheumatology given h/o severe gout,
   and possible septic arthritis for possible elbow tap.
   - Vanco given ED, continue q48
   - Zosyn -> trend LFT's given h/o allergy to unasyn
   - Levaquin given in ED.  Hold for now and consider redosing in 48 hours
   prn.
   - blood cultures, uric acid, rheumatoid factor (for IE w/u), ferritin
   urine legionella, elbow/shoulder films, repeat CXR.
   - Echo to evaluate for vegetations on valves or hardware
   - Rheum consult for possible elbow tap and assistance with gout
   management.
   - trend labs.
   .
   #. ARF: Likely pre-renal from poor-perfusion of kidneys, but must
   consider ATN given hypotension.  Intrinsic renal disease from septic
   emboli would seem less likely.  Trend improving with IVF's.  No
   schistos noted on smear which is reassuring that TTP unlikely (given
   low plt's renal failure).
   - Urine bland.
   - renal U/S when able -> would not transport for renal ultrasound at
   this time until hemodynamics improved.
   - urine lytes
   - follow urine output closely and consider renal c/s if creatinine
   worsening
   - foley catheter
   - Renally dose all medications.
   - Is likely to be torsemide dependent given severe CHF and renal
   failure so would consider dosing torsemide this PM after more fluids or
   if any change to respiratory status.
   .
   # Acid/Base: Admission labs with primary respiratory alkalosis and
   metabolic acidosis.  Trend with lactates.
   .
   #. Elevated INR: likely elevated in the setting of coumadin use with
   other medical problems.
   - hold coumadin and trend given antibiotics.
   - if signs of bleeding, consider vitamin K/FFP
   .
   #. Elevated T. Bili: has been chronically elevated in the past with
   other LFT elevations.  CT unremarkable for obstructive etiology.
   - continue to trend, consider RUQ U/S if rising
   - check haptoglobin, LDH.
   .
   # CHF: Non-ischemic cardiomyopathy with severe TR.
   - Hold carvedilol given shock
   - Hold diovan given shock
   - Hold digoxin and check level -> consider dosing for A. fib if level
   not elevated.
   - Hold torsemide and dose as needed.
   - FYI to primary Cardiologist Dr. [**First Name (STitle) **]
   .
   # Atrial Fibrillation: h/o and returned to with dopamine on board.
   Wean dopamine, hold coumadin and other outpatient medications for now.
   - dose digoxin by level.
   .
   # Sinusitis: By history has had several months of sinus congestion.
   - fluticasone nasal spray
   - antibiotics
   - consider sinus CT
   .
   # Eosinophilia: Absolute count about 900.  Has been noted in the past.
   Concerning for malignancy, occult parasitic infection, Churg-Strasuss
   (does have rhinitis but no h/o asthma and is older than typically
   seen).
   - Check ANCA
   - Trend eosinphils
   - Steroids prn as per rheumatology
   - Rheum consult.
   .
   # Non-specific CT findings: Unclear how to correlate clinically.
   - repeat CT head this PM for further evaluation.
   - consider dedicated sinus CT with this series.
   .
   # Gout: Renally dose allopurinol.
   - Rheum consult for possible tap (has elevated INR)
   - hold colchicine/ibuprofen given renal failure
   .
   # Diabetes: Continue humalog sliding scale.
   .
   # FEN: IVF, replete electrolytes, NPO
   # Prophylaxis: INR supratherapeutic, pneumoboots,  famotidine
   # Access: peripherals, CVL, A-line
   # Communication: Patient and wife who works in Radiology for [**Hospital1 54**]
   # Code:  Full (discussed with patient)
   # Disposition: ICU pending clinical improvement
   ICU Care

Summary:

The patient is a 63-year-old male with a history of severe systolic heart failure, atrial fibrillation, and chronic renal insufficiency, who presents with septic shock. He has been treated with antibiotics, vasopressors, and fluids, and is currently in the ICU. His vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 98.6°F, blood pressure of 101/65 mmHg, and heart rate of 85 beats per minute. His oxygen saturation is 99% on nasal cannula. His laboratory results show elevated levels of creatinine, blood urea nitrogen, and lactate, but his white blood cell count is normal. He has been diagnosed with septic arthritis and is being treated with antibiotics and pain management.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Septic shock: The patient is at risk for further deterioration of his hemodynamic status, which could lead to organ failure and death.
2. Renal failure: The patient's chronic renal insufficiency may worsen, leading to acute kidney injury or failure.
3. Cardiac failure: The patient's severe systolic heart failure may worsen, leading to cardiac arrest or death.
4. Infection: The patient's septic arthritis may lead to further complications, such as sepsis, septic shock, or osteomyelitis.
5. Thrombocytopenia: The patient's platelet count is low, which may increase the risk of bleeding complications.
6. Electrolyte imbalance: The patient's electrolyte levels are abnormal, which may lead to cardiac arrhythmias or muscle weakness.
7. Acid-base imbalance: The patient's acid-base status is abnormal, which may lead to respiratory or cardiac complications.
8. Gout: The patient's gout may worsen, leading to further complications, such as joint damage or kidney failure.
9. Diabetes: The patient's diabetes may worsen, leading to further complications, such as kidney damage or blindness.
10. Atrial fibrillation: The patient's atrial fibrillation may worsen, leading to further complications, such as stroke or heart failure.

Recommendations:

1. Continue to monitor the patient's vital signs and laboratory results closely.
2. Administer antibiotics and vasopressors as needed to treat septic shock and septic arthritis.
3. Monitor the patient's renal function and adjust fluid management accordingly.
4. Monitor the patient's cardiac function and adjust treatment accordingly.
5. Monitor the patient's electrolyte levels and adjust treatment accordingly.
6. Monitor the patient's acid-base status and adjust treatment accordingly.
7. Consider consulting a rheumatologist to manage the patient's gout.
8. Consider consulting an endocrinologist to manage the patient's diabetes.
9. Consider consulting a cardiologist to manage the patient's atrial fibrillation.
10. Consider consulting a nephrologist to manage the patient's chronic renal insufficiency.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a critically ill individual with a complex medical condition. The patient has been admitted to the ICU with a diagnosis of sepsis without organ dysfunction, atrial fibrillation, acute renal failure, diabetes mellitus type II, and hypotension.

The patient's vital signs are unstable, with a fever of 102.5°F (39.2°C), a heart rate of 85 beats per minute, and a blood pressure of 101/65 mmHg. The patient's respiratory status is stable, with an oxygen saturation of 99% on nasal cannula oxygen.

The patient has been receiving vasopressor support with norepinephrine and vasopressin to maintain blood pressure. The patient has also been receiving hydrocortisone for suspected adrenal insufficiency.

The patient's laboratory results indicate acute kidney injury with a creatinine level of 3.7 mg/dL, and the patient is receiving hemodialysis. The patient's glucose level is elevated at 178 mg/dL, indicating hyperglycemia.

The patient's physical examination is notable for a soft and non-tender abdomen, with no organomegaly or rebound tenderness. The patient's extremities are warm and well-perfused, with 2+ pulses.

Potential medical complications that may arise include:

1. Sepsis-related organ dysfunction: The patient's sepsis may progress to organ dysfunction, such as acute respiratory distress syndrome, acute kidney injury, or hepatic dysfunction.
2. Cardiac arrhythmias: The patient's atrial fibrillation may worsen, leading to cardiac complications such as stroke or cardiac arrest.
3. Renal failure: The patient's acute kidney injury may worsen, leading to end-stage renal disease or the need for dialysis.
4. Hyperglycemia: The patient's hyperglycemia may worsen, leading to diabetic ketoacidosis or hyperosmolar nonketotic syndrome.
5. Adrenal insufficiency: The patient's suspected adrenal insufficiency may worsen, leading to adrenal crisis.
6. Pressure ulcers: The patient's prolonged bed rest and immobility may lead to pressure ulcers.
7. Venous thromboembolism: The patient's immobility and central venous catheters may increase the risk of venous thromboembolism.
8. Infection: The patient's sepsis may lead to secondary infections, such as pneumonia or urinary tract infections.

It is essential to closely monitor the patient's condition and adjust treatment accordingly to prevent these potential complications.

Based on the provided progress note, I summarize the patient's health progress as follows:

The patient, a 63-year-old man with a history of systolic heart failure and dilated cardiomyopathy, was admitted to the ICU with septic shock. He received vasopressin and levophed, which were weaned overnight. The patient's vital signs have improved, with a temperature of 102.5°F, heart rate of 77 beats per minute, and blood pressure of 112/66 mmHg.

The patient's physical examination reveals no acute distress, with clear breath sounds, soft and non-tender abdomen, and warm skin. His neurological examination shows that he is attentive, follows simple commands, and responds to verbal stimuli.

Laboratory results show:

* Hemoglobin: 10.9 g/dL
* White blood cell count: 8.1 x 10^9/L
* Platelet count: 137 x 10^9/L
* Creatinine: 227 mg/dL
* Blood urea nitrogen (BUN): 64 mg/dL
* Glucose: 227 mg/dL
* Electrolytes: sodium 128 mEq/L, potassium 5.4 mEq/L, chloride 101 mEq/L
* Troponin-T: <0.01 ng/mL
* Lactic acid: 1.2 mmol/L
* Albumin: 2.9 g/dL
* LDH: 205 IU/L
* Calcium: 8.0 mg/dL
* Magnesium: 2.0 mg/dL
* Phosphorus: 5.3 mg/dL

The patient's medical conditions include atrial fibrillation, acute renal failure, type II diabetes mellitus, hypotension, pain control, and sepsis without organ dysfunction. The patient's laboratory results indicate acute renal failure, elevated INR, and high glucose levels.

Potential medical complications that may arise include:

1. Worsening of acute renal failure, leading to further electrolyte imbalances and potential need for dialysis.
2. Development of septic shock, which may require further vasopressor support and potential need for mechanical ventilation.
3. Increased risk of bleeding due to thrombocytopenia and prolonged INR.
4. Potential for further electrolyte imbalances, such as hyperkalemia or hypokalemia, due to ongoing renal failure and electrolyte disturbances.
5. Risk of developing diabetic ketoacidosis or hyperosmolar nonketotic syndrome due to uncontrolled hyperglycemia.
6. Potential for further cardiac complications, such as cardiac arrhythmias or cardiac failure, due to underlying cardiomyopathy and sepsis.
7. Risk of developing gastrointestinal bleeding due to stress ulceration and potential need for anticoagulation therapy.
8. Potential for further neurological complications, such as seizures or stroke, due to sepsis and potential electrolyte disturbances.

It is essential to closely monitor the patient's vital signs, laboratory results, and clinical status to prevent or manage these potential complications and optimize his care.

   Assessment and Plan:
   Mr. [**Known lastname 12162**] is a 63yo M w/hx of severe systolic HF, EF 15-20%, afib on
   coumadin, who presents with hypotension
   .
   #. Hypotension:  Patient with marked fever, tachypnea, vasodilated on
   initial exam concerning for septic shock possibly from pulmonary source
   as possible pneumonia on CT scan (although normal lactate and normal
   WBC count).  Septic arthritis considered given prominent joint
   complains and history of gout although joint tap negative.  Evidence of
   adrenal insufficiency given symptoms of fever, hypotension, diarrhea,
   high eosinophils, hyponatremia, hyperkalemia then low cortisol with
   failed ACTH stimulation.  Able to wean from vasopressin and wean down
   from levophed over the past 24 hours.
   - levophed as needed for MAP >60 and attempt to wean, may use small
   250cc IVF bolus if necessary
   -CVP goal is likely much higher than typical [**9-9**] given h/o CHF.  Will
   be very difficult to interpret given h/o severe TR.
   - trend lactate
   .
   #. ? infection/sepsis: No clear source clinically and patient has
   remained afebrile, normal white count without any growth on culture. CT
   chest  on admission with opacity atelectasis/pna.  TTE showing no
   evidence of vegetations on valves or hardware
   - fever curve
   - f/u blood, sputum, urine cx
   - consider d/c vancomycin, zosyn, flagyl
   - rheumatology recs, consider repeat tap if clinically worsens and
   appropriate clinical scenario.
   .
   # Adrenal insufficiency: Symptoms include hypotension, fever, diarrhea,
   elevated eosinophils.  Low serum cortisol with failed ACTH stimulation
   test.  Confounding factors that colchicine causes diarrhea, allupurinol
   induces hypereosinophilia.  Abdominal CT with no evidence of adrenal
   pathology.
   - continue hydrocortisone and taper to prednisone once off pressors
   - consider MRI adrenal to r/o hemorrhage while on coumadin or infection
   .
   #Hyperglycemia: poor glucose control in the setting of high dose
   steroids. Poor PO intake yesterday
   -insulin gtt change to tighter insulin SS this AM as takes PO
   - diabetic diet
   - [**Last Name (un) **] consult recs
   .
   #. ARF: Likely pre-renal from poor-perfusion of kidneys, but must
   consider ATN given hypotension.  Intrinsic renal disease from septic
   emboli would seem less likely.  Trend improving with IVF's.  - Urine
   bland.  Normal renal U/S.
   - follow urine output closely and consider renal c/s if creatinine
   worsening
   - Renally dose all medications.
   - Is likely to be torsemide dependent given severe CHF and renal
   failure so would consider dosing torsemide later
   .
   #. Elevated INR: likely elevated in the setting of coumadin use with
   other medical problems.  Trending down after Vit K
   - hold coumadin until INR <4 and trend given antibiotics then restart
   home dose
   - if signs of bleeding, consider vitamin K/FFP
   .
   #. Elevated T. Bili: has been chronically elevated in the past with
   other LFT elevations.  CT unremarkable for obstructive etiology.
   Trending down
   .
   # CHF: Non-ischemic cardiomyopathy with severe TR.
   - Hold carvedilol given shock
   - Hold diovan given shock
   - Restart digoxin at home dose given low level this AM
   - Hold torsemide and dose as needed.
   - FYI to primary Cardiologist Dr. [**First Name (STitle) **]
   .
   # Atrial Fibrillation: h/o and returned to with dopamine on board.
   Wean dopamine, hold coumadin and other outpatient medications for now.
   - dose digoxin by level.
   .
   # Sinusitis: By history has had several months of sinus congestion.
   - fluticasone nasal spray
   - antibiotics
   - consider sinus CT
   .
   # Eosinophilia: Absolute count about 900.  Has been noted in the past.
   Concerning for malignancy, occult parasitic infection, Churg-Strasuss
   (does have rhinitis but no h/o asthma and is older than typically
   seen).
   - Check ANCA
   - Trend eosinphils
   - Steroids prn as per rheumatology
   - Add on diff to AM labs
   - Rheum consult.
 F/U recs
   .
   # Gout: Renally dose allopurinol. No fluid to tap.
   - F/u rheum recs
   - hold colchicine/ibuprofen given renal failure.
   # FEN: IVF, replete/trend electrolytes, ADAT

   Assessment and Plan
   Assessment and Plan:
   Mr. [**Known lastname 12162**] is a 63yo M w/hx of severe systolic HF, EF 15-20%, afib on
   coumadin, who presents with hypotension
   .
   #. Hypotension:  Patient with marked fever, tachypnea, vasodilated on
   initial exam concerning for septic shock possibly from pulmonary source
   as possible pneumonia on CT scan (although normal lactate and normal
   WBC count).  Septic arthritis considered given prominent joint
   complains and history of gout although joint tap negative.  Evidence of
   adrenal insufficiency given symptoms of fever, hypotension, diarrhea,
   high eosinophils, hyponatremia, hyperkalemia then low cortisol with
   failed ACTH stimulation.  Able to wean from vasopressin and wean down
   from levophed over the past 24 hours.
   - levophed as needed for MAP >60 and attempt to wean, may use small
   250cc IVF bolus if necessary
   -CVP goal is likely much higher than typical [**9-9**] given h/o CHF.  Will
   be very difficult to interpret given h/o severe TR.
   - trend lactate
   .
   #. ? infection/sepsis: No clear source clinically and patient has
   remained afebrile, normal white count without any growth on culture. CT
   chest  on admission with opacity atelectasis/pna.  TTE showing no
   evidence of vegetations on valves or hardware
   - fever curve
   - f/u blood, sputum, urine cx
   - consider d/c vancomycin, zosyn, flagyl
   - rheumatology recs, consider repeat tap if clinically worsens and
   appropriate clinical scenario.
   .
   # Adrenal insufficiency: Symptoms include hypotension, fever, diarrhea,
   elevated eosinophils.  Low serum cortisol with failed ACTH stimulation
   test.  Confounding factors that colchicine causes diarrhea, allupurinol
   induces hypereosinophilia.  Abdominal CT with no evidence of adrenal
   pathology.
   - continue hydrocortisone and taper to prednisone once off pressors
   - consider MRI adrenal to r/o hemorrhage while on coumadin or infection
   .
   #Hyperglycemia: poor glucose control in the setting of high dose
   steroids. Poor PO intake yesterday
   -insulin gtt change to tighter insulin SS this AM as takes PO
   - diabetic diet
   - [**Last Name (un) **] consult recs
   .
   #. ARF: Likely pre-renal from poor-perfusion of kidneys, but must
   consider ATN given hypotension.  Intrinsic renal disease from septic
   emboli would seem less likely.  Trend improving with IVF's.  - Urine
   bland.  Normal renal U/S.
   - follow urine output closely and consider renal c/s if creatinine
   worsening
   - Renally dose all medications.
   - Is likely to be torsemide dependent given severe CHF and renal
   failure so would consider dosing torsemide later
   .
   #. Elevated INR: likely elevated in the setting of coumadin use with
   other medical problems.  Trending down after Vit K
   - hold coumadin until INR <4 and trend given antibiotics then restart
   home dose
   - if signs of bleeding, consider vitamin K/FFP
   .
   #. Elevated T. Bili: has been chronically elevated in the past with
   other LFT elevations.  CT unremarkable for obstructive etiology.
   Trending down
   .
   # CHF: Non-ischemic cardiomyopathy with severe TR.
   - Hold carvedilol given shock
   - Hold diovan given shock
   - Restart digoxin at home dose given low level this AM
   - Hold torsemide and dose as needed.
   - FYI to primary Cardiologist Dr. [**First Name (STitle) **]
   .
   # Atrial Fibrillation: h/o and returned to with dopamine on board.
   Wean dopamine, hold coumadin and other outpatient medications for now.
   - dose digoxin by level.
   .
   # Sinusitis: By history has had several months of sinus congestion.
   - fluticasone nasal spray
   - antibiotics
   - consider sinus CT
   .
   # Eosinophilia: Absolute count about 900.  Has been noted in the past.
   Concerning for malignancy, occult parasitic infection, Churg-Strasuss
   (does have rhinitis but no h/o asthma and is older than typically
   seen).
   - Check ANCA
   - Trend eosinphils
   - Steroids prn as per rheumatology
   - Add on diff to AM labs
   - Rheum consult.
 F/U recs
   .
   # Gout: Renally dose allopurinol. No fluid to tap.
   - F/u rheum recs
   - hold colchicine/ibuprofen given renal failure.
   # FEN: IVF, replete/trend electrolytes, ADAT
   # Prophylaxis: INR supratherapeutic, pneumoboots,  famotidine
   # Access: peripherals, CVL, A-line
   # Communication: Patient and wife who works in Radiology for [**Hospital1 54**]
   # Code:  Full (discussed with patient)
   # Disposition: ICU pending clinical improvement

Based on the patient's progress note, the following potential medical complications can arise:

1. Infection/Sepsis: The patient has a history of pneumonia, and the CT chest scan showed left lower lobe atelectasis or pneumonia. The patient's symptoms include fever, tachypnea, and vasodilation, which are concerning for septic shock. The patient's laboratory results show elevated eosinophils, which may indicate an allergic response or an inflammatory process.
2. Adrenal Insufficiency: The patient has symptoms of hypotension, fever, diarrhea, and elevated eosinophils, which are consistent with adrenal insufficiency. The patient's laboratory results show low serum cortisol with failed ACTH stimulation test, which confirms the diagnosis.
3. Hyperglycemia: The patient has poor glucose control, which is exacerbated by high-dose steroids. The patient's blood glucose levels are elevated, and the patient is at risk for developing diabetic ketoacidosis or hyperosmolar hyperglycemic nonketotic syndrome.
4. Acute Renal Failure (ARF): The patient has a history of severe systolic heart failure and is at risk for developing ARF due to poor perfusion of the kidneys. The patient's laboratory results show elevated creatinine and blood urea nitrogen (BUN) levels, which are consistent with ARF.
5. Electrolyte Imbalance: The patient has an electrolyte imbalance, with hypokalemia and hypomagnesemia. The patient's laboratory results show low potassium and magnesium levels, which can exacerbate cardiac arrhythmias and muscle weakness.
6. Cardiac Complications: The patient has a history of atrial fibrillation and severe tricuspid regurgitation, which increases the risk of cardiac complications such as heart failure, arrhythmias, and thromboembolic events.
7. Respiratory Complications: The patient has a history of pneumonia and chronic sinus congestion, which increases the risk of respiratory complications such as respiratory failure, pneumonia, and sinusitis.
8. Gastrointestinal Complications: The patient has a history of diarrhea, which may be caused by antibiotic-associated diarrhea or inflammatory bowel disease. The patient's laboratory results show elevated eosinophils, which may indicate an allergic response or an inflammatory process.

In summary, the patient is at risk for developing various medical complications, including infection/sepsis, adrenal insufficiency, hyperglycemia, ARF, electrolyte imbalance, cardiac complications, respiratory complications, and gastrointestinal complications. The patient's condition requires close monitoring and management to prevent and treat these complications.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient's condition appears to be stable, with some notable changes and concerns. The patient's vasopressor support has been weaned down to 0.04, indicating some improvement in their hemodynamic status. However, the presence of left lower lobe atelectasis or pneumonia on CT chest suggests that the patient may still be at risk for respiratory complications.

The patient's glucose levels have been elevated, with fingersticks >400, and they have been started on insulin gtt overnight. This is likely due to the patient's underlying condition and potential stress response.

The patient's laboratory results show some abnormalities, including elevated transaminases, alkaline phosphatase, and lactate dehydrogenase (LDH) levels. The patient's calcium, magnesium, and phosphorus levels are within normal limits. The patient's coagulation profile is abnormal, with a PT/PTT/INR of 43.6/50.3/4.6 (11.5), suggesting a bleeding diathesis.

Potential medical complications that can arise from these findings include:

1. Respiratory failure due to left lower lobe atelectasis or pneumonia.
2. Hyperglycemic crisis due to insulin resistance and stress response.
3. Bleeding complications due to the patient's abnormal coagulation profile.
4. Hepatic dysfunction due to elevated transaminases and alkaline phosphatase levels.
5. Electrolyte imbalances due to abnormal calcium, magnesium, and phosphorus levels.
6. Potential adrenal insufficiency, given the consideration for adrenal MRI to evaluate adrenal insufficiency.

It is essential to closely monitor the patient's condition and adjust their treatment plan accordingly to prevent these potential complications.

   Assessment and Plan:
   Mr. [**Known lastname 12162**] is a 63yo M w/hx of severe systolic HF, EF 15-20%, afib on
   coumadin, who presents with hypotension
   .
   #. Hypotension:  Patient with marked fever, vasodilation, tachypnea on
   initial exam more consistent with septic shock possibly from pulmonary
   source as possible pneumonia on CT scan (although normal lactate and
   normal WBC count).  Septic arthritis considered given prominent joint
   complains and history of gout although joint tap negative.  Adrenal
   insufficiency considered given low cortisol on admission and <25%
   response to cosyntropin may be primary or functional in setting of
   acute illness .  PE considered although supratherapeutic INR.  Able to
   wean from vasopressin and wean from levophed over the past 24 hours.
   -  MAP goal 60-65.  [**Month (only) 60**] need to be less aggressive with MAP target of
   60 rather than typical 65 given h/o EF 10-15%, but previous BP's noted
   to be normal.
   - levophed as needed for MAP >60 and attempt to wean, may use small
   250cc IVF bolus if necessary
   CVP goal is likely much higher than typical [**9-9**] given h/o CHF.  Will
   be very difficult to interpret given h/o severe TR.  Would continue to
   give fluids for now and monitor respiratory status.
   - trend lactate
   .
   #. Infection/Sepsis: No clear source clinically although evidence of
   pneumonia on chest imaging.  TTE showing no evidence of vegetations on
   the valves or hardware
   - f/u blood, sputum, urine cx
   - continue vancomycin, zosyn, flagyl
   - Zosyn -> trend LFT's given h/o allergy to unasy-
   - Rheum consult for possible elbow tap and assistance with gout
   management.
   - trend labs.
   .
   # Adrenal insufficiency: Symptoms include hypotension, fever, diarrhea,
   elevated eosinophils.  Low serum cortisol with failed ACTH stimulation
   test.  Confounding factors that colchicine causes diarrhea, allupurinol
   induces hypereosinophilia.  Abdominal CT with no evidence of adrenal
   pathology.
   - continue hydrocortisone and taper to prednisone once off pressors
   - consider MRI adrenal to r/o hemorrhage while on coumadin or infection
   .
   #Hyperglycemia: poor glucose control in the setting of high dose
   steroids
   -insulin gtt change to tighter insulin SS this AM
   - [**Last Name (un) **] consult recs
   #. ARF: Likely pre-renal from poor-perfusion of kidneys, but must
   consider ATN given hypotension.  Intrinsic renal disease from septic
   emboli would seem less likely.  Trend improving with IVF's.  - Urine
   bland.  Normal renal U/S.
   - follow urine output closely and consider renal c/s if creatinine
   worsening
   - Renally dose all medications.
   - Is likely to be torsemide dependent given severe CHF and renal
   failure so would consider dosing torsemide this PM after more fluids or
   if any change to respiratory status.
   - PM lytes/creatinine
   .
   #. Elevated INR: likely elevated in the setting of coumadin use with
   other medical problems.  Trending down after Vit K
   - hold coumadin and trend given antibiotics.
   - if signs of bleeding, consider vitamin K/FFP
   .
   #. Elevated T. Bili: has been chronically elevated in the past with
   other LFT elevations.  CT unremarkable for obstructive etiology.
   Trending down
   .
   # CHF: Non-ischemic cardiomyopathy with severe TR.
   - Hold carvedilol given shock
   - Hold diovan given shock
   - Restart digoxin given low level this AM
   - Hold torsemide and dose as needed.
   - FYI to primary Cardiologist Dr. [**First Name (STitle) **]
   .
   # Atrial Fibrillation: h/o and returned to with dopamine on board.
   Wean dopamine, hold coumadin and other outpatient medications for now.
   - dose digoxin by level.
   .
   # Sinusitis: By history has had several months of sinus congestion.
   - fluticasone nasal spray
   - antibiotics
   - consider sinus CT
   .
   # Eosinophilia: Absolute count about 900.  Has been noted in the past.
   Concerning for malignancy, occult parasitic infection, Churg-Strasuss
   (does have rhinitis but no h/o asthma and is older than typically
   seen).
   - Check ANCA
   - Trend eosinphils
   - Steroids prn as per rheumatology
   - Add on diff to AM labs
   - Rheum consult.
 F/U recs
   .
   # Non-specific CT findings: Unclear how to correlate clinically.
   - repeat CT head this PM for further evaluation.
   - consider dedicated sinus CT with this series.
   .
   # Gout: Renally dose allopurinol. No fluid to tap.
   - F/u rheum recs
   - hold colchicine/ibuprofen given renal failure.

Based on the physician's daily progress note, the patient is a 63-year-old male with a history of severe systolic heart failure, EF 15-20%, atrial fibrillation, and coumadin use. The patient presents with hypotension, fever, and tachypnea, which is consistent with septic shock possibly from a pulmonary source. The patient has a low cortisol level on admission and a <25% response to cosyntropin, which suggests adrenal insufficiency.

The patient's current medications include vancomycin, zosyn, flagyl, and hydrocortisone, and he is receiving insulin via a continuous infusion. The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 36.5°C, heart rate of 70 bpm, and blood pressure of 99/52 mmHg.

The patient's laboratory results show:

* White blood cell count: 8.1 K/μL
* Hemoglobin: 9.6 g/dL
* Platelet count: 137 K/μL
* Creatinine: 3.7 mg/dL
* Blood urea nitrogen: 105 mg/dL
* Glucose: 178 mg/dL
* Lactic acid: 1.2 mmol/L
* Albumin: 2.9 g/dL
* LDH: 158 IU/L
* Calcium: 8.1 mg/dL
* Magnesium: 2.3 mg/dL
* Phosphorus: 3.7 mg/dL

The patient's chest X-ray shows left lower lobe atelectasis or pneumonia, and his CT scan is normal.

The patient's current medical issues include:

* Hypotension: The patient's blood pressure is low, and he is receiving vasopressors to support his blood pressure.
* Infection/Sepsis: The patient has evidence of pneumonia on his chest X-ray, and he is receiving antibiotics.
* Adrenal insufficiency: The patient has low cortisol levels and a <25% response to cosyntropin, which suggests adrenal insufficiency.
* Hyperglycemia: The patient's glucose levels are elevated, and he is receiving insulin via a continuous infusion.
* ARF: The patient's creatinine levels are elevated, and he is receiving IV fluids to support his kidney function.
* Elevated INR: The patient's INR is elevated, which is likely due to his coumadin use and other medical problems.
* Elevated T. Bili: The patient's T. Bili levels are elevated, which is likely due to his liver dysfunction.
* CHF: The patient has a history of non-ischemic cardiomyopathy with severe TR.
* Atrial Fibrillation: The patient has a history of atrial fibrillation and is currently in atrial fibrillation.
* Sinusitis: The patient has a history of sinus congestion and is receiving antibiotics.
* Eosinophilia: The patient's eosinophil count is elevated, which is concerning for malignancy, occult parasitic infection, or Churg-Strasuss syndrome.

The patient's potential medical complications include:

* Sepsis: The patient is at risk for sepsis due to his pneumonia and adrenal insufficiency.
* Adrenal crisis: The patient is at risk for adrenal crisis due to his adrenal insufficiency and low cortisol levels.
* Kidney injury: The patient is at risk for kidney injury due to his ARF and IV fluid therapy.
* Liver dysfunction: The patient is at risk for liver dysfunction due to his elevated T. Bili levels and liver disease.
* Cardiac arrhythmias: The patient is at risk for cardiac arrhythmias due to his atrial fibrillation and CHF.
* Respiratory failure: The patient is at risk for respiratory failure due to his pneumonia and CHF.

The patient's plan of care includes:

* Continuing vasopressors to support his blood pressure
* Continuing antibiotics for his pneumonia
* Continuing hydrocortisone and tapering to prednisone once off pressors
* Continuing insulin via a continuous infusion
* Trending his laboratory results, including his creatinine, glucose, and liver function tests
* Monitoring his vital signs and respiratory status
* Considering a MRI adrenal to rule out hemorrhage or infection
* Considering a renal consultation to evaluate his kidney function and plan for further management.

   chest  on admission with opacity atelectasis/pna.  TTE showing no
   evidence of vegetations on valves or hardware
   - fever curve
   - f/u blood, sputum, urine cx
   - d/c vancomycin, zosyn, flagyl as all cultures have been negative and
   monitor clinically
   - rheumatology recs, consider repeat tap if clinically worsens and
   appropriate clinical scenario.
   .
   # Adrenal insufficiency: Symptoms include hypotension, fever, diarrhea,
   elevated eosinophils.  Low serum cortisol with failed ACTH stimulation
   test.  Confounding factors that colchicine causes diarrhea, allupurinol
   induces hypereosinophilia.  Abdominal CT with no evidence of adrenal
   pathology.
   - continue hydrocortisone, but likely will start oral in [**1-30**] days and
   taper
   - consider MRI adrenal to r/o hemorrhage while on coumadin or infection
   .
   #Hyperglycemia: poor glucose control in the setting of high dose
   steroids. Poor PO intake yesterday
   -insulin gtt change to tighter insulin SS this AM as takes PO
   - diabetic diet
   - [**Last Name (un) **] consult recs
   .
   #. ARF: Likely pre-renal from poor-perfusion of kidneys, but must
   consider ATN given hypotension.  Intrinsic renal disease from septic
   emboli would seem less likely.  Trend improving with IVF's.  - Urine
   bland.  Normal renal U/S.
   - follow urine output closely and consider renal c/s if creatinine
   worsening
   - Renally dose all medications.
   - hold [**Last Name (un) 239**]
   - Is likely to be torsemide dependent given severe CHF and renal
   failure so would consider dosing torsemide later
   .
   #. Elevated INR: likely elevated in the setting of coumadin use with
   other medical problems.  Trending down after Vit K
   - hold coumadin until INR <4 and trend given antibiotics then restart
   home dose
   - if signs of bleeding, consider vitamin K/FFP
   .
   #. Elevated T. Bili: has been chronically elevated in the past with
   other LFT elevations.  CT unremarkable for obstructive etiology.
   Trending down
   .
   # CHF: Non-ischemic cardiomyopathy with severe TR.
   - Hold carvedilol given shock
   - Hold diovan given shock
   - Restart digoxin at home dose given low level this AM
   - Hold torsemide and dose as needed.
   - FYI to primary Cardiologist Dr. [**First Name (STitle) **]
   .
   # Atrial Fibrillation: h/o and returned to with dopamine on board.
   Wean dopamine, hold coumadin and other outpatient medications for now.
   - dose digoxin by level.
   .
   # Sinusitis: By history has had several months of sinus congestion.
   - fluticasone nasal spray
   - antibiotics
   - consider sinus CT
   .
   # Eosinophilia: Absolute count about 900.  Has been noted in the past.
   Concerning for malignancy, occult parasitic infection, Churg-Strasuss
   (does have rhinitis but no h/o asthma and is older than typically
   seen).
   - Check ANCA

   - Add on diff to AM labs
   - Rheum consult.
 F/U recs
   .

Based on the physician's daily progress note, the patient is a 63-year-old male with a history of severe systolic heart failure, atrial fibrillation, and gout. He is currently in the ICU due to hypotension, fever, and tachypnea, which are concerning for septic shock possibly from a pulmonary source.

The patient has been weaned off vasopressin and levophed, and his blood pressure is stable. However, he is still requiring insulin therapy to control his blood sugar levels.

The patient has a number of potential medical complications that need to be monitored and managed. These include:

1. Infection/sepsis: The patient has a fever and tachypnea, which are concerning for infection. He has a CT chest showing left lower lobe atelectasis or pneumonia, and his white blood cell count is normal. However, his eosinophil count is elevated, which could be a sign of an allergic reaction or parasitic infection.
2. Adrenal insufficiency: The patient has symptoms of fever, hypotension, diarrhea, and elevated eosinophils, which are consistent with adrenal insufficiency. He has a low serum cortisol level and failed ACTH stimulation test.
3. Hyperglycemia: The patient has poor glucose control, which is likely due to his high-dose steroid therapy. He is also experiencing poor oral intake, which could contribute to his hyperglycemia.
4. ARF: The patient has acute kidney injury, which is likely due to pre-renal failure from poor perfusion of his kidneys. However, it is also possible that he has ATN or intrinsic renal disease from septic emboli.
5. Elevated INR: The patient's INR is elevated due to his coumadin therapy, which is likely contributing to his bleeding risk.
6. Elevated T. Bili: The patient's T. Bili is chronically elevated, which could be due to a variety of causes, including liver disease or bile duct obstruction.
7. CHF: The patient has non-ischemic cardiomyopathy with severe TR, which is likely contributing to his heart failure.

The patient's medications need to be carefully monitored and managed to prevent potential complications. These include:

1. Insulin: The patient's insulin therapy needs to be carefully monitored to prevent hypoglycemia or hyperglycemia.
2. Vasopressors: The patient's vasopressor therapy needs to be carefully monitored to prevent hypotension or hypertension.
3. Antibiotics: The patient's antibiotics need to be carefully monitored to prevent antibiotic-associated diarrhea or other complications.
4. Steroids: The patient's steroid therapy needs to be carefully monitored to prevent adrenal insufficiency or other complications.
5. Renal medications: The patient's renal medications need to be carefully monitored to prevent kidney injury or other complications.

The patient's care plan should include:

1. Close monitoring of his vital signs, laboratory results, and clinical status.
2. Management of his infection/sepsis, adrenal insufficiency, hyperglycemia, ARF, elevated INR, and elevated T. Bili.
3. Careful monitoring and management of his medications, including insulin, vasopressors, antibiotics, steroids, and renal medications.
4. Consideration of imaging studies, such as a CT scan or MRI, to further evaluate his condition.
5. Consultation with specialists, such as a cardiologist or nephrologist, to provide additional guidance and support.

   Assessment and Plan:
   Mr. [**Known lastname 12162**] is a 63yo M w/hx of severe systolic HF, EF 15-20%, afib on
   coumadin, who presents with hypotension
   .
   #. Hypotension:  Patient with marked fever, tachypnea, vasodilated on
   initial exam concerning for septic shock possibly from pulmonary source
   as possible pneumonia on CT scan (although normal lactate and normal
   WBC count).  Septic arthritis considered given prominent joint
   complains and history of gout although joint tap negative.  Evidence of
   adrenal insufficiency given symptoms of fever, hypotension, diarrhea,
   high eosinophils, hyponatremia, hyperkalemia then low cortisol with
   failed ACTH stimulation.  Able to wean from vasopressin and wean down
   from levophed over the past 24 hours.
   - levophed as needed for MAP >60 and attempt to wean, may use small
   250cc IVF bolus if necessary
   -CVP goal is likely much higher than typical [**9-9**] given h/o CHF.  Will
   be very difficult to interpret given h/o severe TR.
   - trend lactate
   .
   #. ? infection/sepsis: No clear source clinically and patient has
   remained afebrile, normal white count without any growth on culture. CT
   chest  on admission with opacity atelectasis/pna.  TTE showing no
   evidence of vegetations on valves or hardware
   - fever curve
   - f/u blood, sputum, urine cx
   - consider d/c vancomycin, zosyn, flagyl
   - rheumatology recs, consider repeat tap if clinically worsens and
   appropriate clinical scenario.
   .
   # Adrenal insufficiency: Symptoms include hypotension, fever, diarrhea,
   elevated eosinophils.  Low serum cortisol with failed ACTH stimulation
   test.  Confounding factors that colchicine causes diarrhea, allupurinol
   induces hypereosinophilia.  Abdominal CT with no evidence of adrenal
   pathology.
   - continue hydrocortisone and taper to prednisone once off pressors
   - consider MRI adrenal to r/o hemorrhage while on coumadin or infection
   .
   #Hyperglycemia: poor glucose control in the setting of high dose
   steroids. Poor PO intake yesterday
   -insulin gtt change to tighter insulin SS this AM as takes PO
   - diabetic diet
   - [**Last Name (un) **] consult recs
   .
   #. ARF: Likely pre-renal from poor-perfusion of kidneys, but must
   consider ATN given hypotension.  Intrinsic renal disease from septic
   emboli would seem less likely.  Trend improving with IVF's.  - Urine
   bland.  Normal renal U/S.
   - follow urine output closely and consider renal c/s if creatinine
   worsening
   - Renally dose all medications.
   - Is likely to be torsemide dependent given severe CHF and renal
   failure so would consider dosing torsemide later
   - PM lytes/creatinine
   .
   #. Elevated INR: likely elevated in the setting of coumadin use with
   other medical problems.  Trending down after Vit K
   - hold coumadin and trend given antibiotics.
   - if signs of bleeding, consider vitamin K/FFP
   .
   #. Elevated T. Bili: has been chronically elevated in the past with
   other LFT elevations.  CT unremarkable for obstructive etiology.
   Trending down
   .
   # CHF: Non-ischemic cardiomyopathy with severe TR.
   - Hold carvedilol given shock
   - Hold diovan given shock
   - Restart digoxin given low level this AM
   - Hold torsemide and dose as needed.
   - FYI to primary Cardiologist Dr. [**First Name (STitle) **]
   .
   # Atrial Fibrillation: h/o and returned to with dopamine on board.
   Wean dopamine, hold coumadin and other outpatient medications for now.
   - dose digoxin by level.
   .
   # Sinusitis: By history has had several months of sinus congestion.
   - fluticasone nasal spray
   - antibiotics
   - consider sinus CT
   .
   # Eosinophilia: Absolute count about 900.  Has been noted in the past.
   Concerning for malignancy, occult parasitic infection, Churg-Strasuss
   (does have rhinitis but no h/o asthma and is older than typically
   seen).
   - Check ANCA
   - Trend eosinphils
   - Steroids prn as per rheumatology
   - Add on diff to AM labs
   - Rheum consult.
 F/U recs
   .
   # Non-specific CT findings: Unclear how to correlate clinically.
   - repeat CT head this PM for further evaluation.
   - consider dedicated sinus CT with this series.
   .
   # Gout: Renally dose allopurinol. No fluid to tap.
   - F/u rheum recs
   - hold colchicine/ibuprofen given renal failure.
   # FEN: IVF, replete/trend electrolytes, ADAT
